FacilityName: South Central FS, Inc. Ramsey Plant

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Facility Accidental Release and emergency Response Policy.

    The management and employees of South Central FS, Inc. are committed to the prevention of any accidental released of anhydrous ammonia.  If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the local fire department, or other authorities, to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment.

The Stationary Source and the Regulated Substances Handled.

    The primary activity at the facility, which is located at 314 e 6th ST, is the storage and blending of fertilizers for sale to farmers.  Anhydrous Ammonia is received, stored, and distributed for direct application as a crop production nutrient. The storage and handling system consists  of 47,700 gallon storage tank, loading risers, associated plumbing and nurse tanks. Access to the site is restricted to authorized facility employees, authorized management personnel and authorized contractors. 

 The maximum quantity of anhydrous ammonia that can be stored would be 175,000 pounds.  

The Accidental Release Prevention Program.

    The facility complies with EPA?s accidental release prevention rule and with all applicable state codes and regulations.  This facility has implemented the provisions of ?Safety Requirements for the storage and handling of anhydrous ammonia, K-61.1?, published by the American National Standards Institute, Inc.  As adopted by State Regulations and the standards of the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, ?Storage and handling of anhydrous ammonia.?

Five Year Accident History.

    The following is a list of accidental released in the past 5 years that have occurred at the facility: None to Report

The Emergency Response Program.
    
    The Facility has:
-    A written emergency action plan, in accordance with OSHA Standard, 29, CFR 1910.38:
-    Provided state and local authorities the emergency planning and community right-to-know information a

s required under SARA Title III (EPCRA):
-    A written emergency response plan, in accordance with OSHA Standard, 29, CFR 1910.120, including pre-emergency planning and employee training.

Planning Changes to Improve Safety

    Safety improvement is an on-going process at the facility.  Periodic evaluations are performed to assess the maintenance of safe condition.  In (2000) we plan to do extensive maintenance and upgrade the facility to meet new state regulations for the handling and storage of anhydrous ammonia.
